title: Autonomous Boat Water Cannon - Water Delivery System for RoboBoat 2024 and 2025
overview: The goal of this project was to design and build a water cannon mounted on the autonomous boat Barka, capable of shooting water targets.
The system was developed as part of the RoboBoat 2024 competition, where water target engagement was one of the required missions.
A key constraint was simplicity and the use of components already available within the student research group.
highlights: The entire water cannon system - from initial concept through mechanical design, and embedded software - was independently designed and implemented by me end to end.
The water cannon consists of a DC diaphragm pump drawing water directly from the lake and a custom-designed nozzle manufactured using 3D printing.
The mechanical design allows the entire cannon assembly to be quickly detached for transport or when not required during missions.
The system was fully integrated with the boat's onboard software, supporting both remote manual control and autonomous operation modes.
Control commands and status feedback were handled through the existing boat communication and control architecture (CAN, CRSF).
The solution was later reused and retained as a required subsystem for the RoboBoat 2025 competition.
results: The water cannon operated reliably during testing and competition runs, successfully engaging water targets.
The simple and modular design proved easy to maintain and reuse across multiple seasons (RoboBoat 2024 and 2025).
Limitations included limited shooting range and accuracy, mainly due to pump pressure constraints and lack of closed-loop aiming control.
Future improvements could include pressure regulation, closed-loop aiming using vision feedback, and improved nozzle geometry.
